author: chfast
content: I know the EIP, but who though this is good idea? Coinbase address is never empty (except for JSON tests of course).

author: peter.davies
content: In theory, post merge, you could clear an empty account by proposing an empty block and naming the empty account as fee recipient. According to EIP 161, that should result in the account being cleared. This would have been a messy edgecase with security implications, if there were any empty accounts left on Mainnet.

author: peter.davies
content: That's the wrong EIP, should be EIP 161.

author: peter.davies
content: My point was that it is likely that clients have implemented "send zero transactions fees to coinbase" inconsistently, given that is was an untested edgecase that couldn't happen prior to the merge.

author: chfast
content: This EIP is so old nobody thought about the PoS world for sure.

author: peter.davies
content: Because coinbase would recieve the block reward and not get deleted.

author: peter.davies
content: Actually there is a complicated situation when the empty account has storage. If the first transaction in a block (with the empty account as coinbase) pays no gas fee, the account is deleted and resurrected by the block reward later (without storage). Otherwise the account becomes non-empty and keeps its storage.

author: peter.davies
content: I have not met anyone who thinks that EIP 161 is well written or that the authors thought though all the edgecases carefully. Given that it was designed, implemented and deployed in about a month as a crisis response to the Shanghai DOS attacks, I don't feel the need to be too critical of them.
